nodes.bodyText: It shouldn't be necessary to extend TestCase - we use JUnit 4, and TestCase is a JUnit 3 thing.
This exception should be wrapped and rethrown, probably in a MalformedQueryException. Also, I think you should catch RDFParseException and rethrow it wrapped in a MalformedQueryException.

I think it should throw a MalformedQueryException rather than an RDFParseException - similar to how other syntactically illegal queries or updates result in a MalformedQueryException. You could wrap the RDFParseException produced by the parser in it so the cause is clear.
You don't need to do this when the datablock is empty.

Hey @jeenbroekstra, thanks for the valuable feedback. We are facing the following error when adding SPARQLUpdateDataBlockParser in the SPARQLParser.java file -
"Adding dependency on module 'rdf4j-repository-sail' will introduce circular dependency between modules 'rdf4j-queryalgebra-evaluation' and 'rdf4j-queryparser-sparql'" .
Let us know how to proceed. Meanwhile, we are trying to figure out some other way to parse datablocks.

@ishaanbassi Ah good point, I hadn't thought of that. This will require a bit of refactoring. I suggest you move the SPARQLUpdateDatablockParser class to package org.eclipse.rdf4j.query.parser.sparql, in the rdf4j-queryparser-sparql module. That should solve the circular dependency issue. You will also need to add a new dependency for the trig parser to the pom.xml in the rdf4j-queryparser-sparql module:
	<dependency>
		<groupId>${project.groupId}</groupId>
		<artifactId>rdf4j-rio-trig</artifactId>
		<version>${project.version}</version>
	</dependency>

To preserve backward compatibility, leave an empty class with the old name in the old location, marked @deprecated.
You know, I was actually doing these change while writing this, to make sure I wasn't making a mistake. I might as well push to your branch, so you can see what I mean.
In JUnit 4, rather than @Override, this should have a @Before annotation.
Why is it reporting line 7, on a one-line update? That can't be right.

Ah, I only just now noticed that this was an existing, commented-out test class that you added your test to. I don't think that's quite right, let me have a closer look and I'll try and give some advice on how to better organize this.
Yeah, I think you should undo this, leave this old class commented out, and move your tests to the SPARQLUpdateTest test suite. See my other comment, below, for details.

Thanks for the help @jeenbroekstra . We have done all the changes suggested above.
We also noted one thing in the SPARQLParser.java file. In case the updateNode itself is not null, then do we need to check separately that the datablock is empty? We have kept this condition for now.

Yeah, I think that how you currently have it is correct: you only want to process the datablock if it is not empty. Even if updateNode is not null, it can still be a different type of update, e.g. a  Modify operation, in which case there is no datablock to parse.
I don't think it matters too much because the parser will return very quickly on an empty string, but I think doing a quick string equality check is marginally more efficient.

@jeenbroekstra, we found that the failing testcases in ShaclTest, are due to this condition on readCodePoint function. Hence, we are not sure if these changes are sufficient. Kindly suggest an alternative solution or you can push a fix. Thanks for the help!

The problem is that you are looking at the wrong character. You haven't advanced c yet, so it's still the last processed char - which will never be equal to '.' or '}', so the end char is never read. This is what causes the failures in the SHACL tests.
To fix, add this line before your if-condition:
	c = peekCodePoint();

That sets the value of c to the next char to be read, and then we decide to actually read if it is indeed a full stop or a closing bracket. Note that we use peek instead of read so that if the character isn't one we need to skip over, we haven't removed it for future processing yet.
